text: this is a arscott chief film critic at
the new york times and today we're going
to take a look at the Academy Award
nominees for Best Animated Short if I
had to pick one favorite I think it
would be me and my Moulton which is in a
way visually the simplest and it's a
story about a young girl growing up in
the mid-60s in Norway whose parents are
eccentric modernist architects ten
thousand men in our town one single
mustache and it has to be on my dad
what's great about it is that in this
very simple straightforward sweet story
there's a lot of detail it's a very
subtle and very touching and very
beautifully made and drawn story Wow
you look like an installation at the
Contemporary Art Museum I would say that
the favorites are maybe feast which
comes from the Disney Animation Studios
which is very lively and fun it's about
a dog with a huge appetite and it kind
of tells the whole story of the dogs
masters romantic life which you see in
the background as you mostly see the dog
just eating all of the food that you
couldn't get to
it's sentimental it'll kind of make you
laugh it'll choke you up a little bit
it's a it's a very bold and imaginative
movie
another animated short that I think has
a chance is a single life which tells
the story of a woman's entire life in
just a couple of minutes through a song
that she listens to she gets a record of
the song a single life and as it skips
around back and forth you see different
phases of her life and it's a very
touching very clever very surprising
little movie a bigger picture is a story
of two brothers caring for their aging
mother and facing the prospect of her
death and also their own sibling rivalry
what's distinctive about this is the
style it combines drawn flat animation
with stop motion technique so the movie
is happening simultaneously in three and
two dimensions
the dam keeper is a really lovely movie
it's using pencil drawn animated
techniques that are very kind of smudgy
and blurry and then sometimes very very
sharp it's about a small pig whose job
is keeping the dam that protects the
town he lives in from this enormous dust
cloud it's the kind of movie it doesn't
ever explain to you what it's about and
it leaves you with a very strong sense
of having gone to a wonderfully imagined
world the animated shorts as always show
what a vital and diverse form of
filmmaking animation is in a way that we
don't always see with the big Hollywood
family blockbusters if you want to see
where the state of the art is right now
you can look at these five movies and
really get a very strong sense of that
